events.name: DCD>Zettastructure - Day 2
events.description: As the IoT, Smart Cities, Big Data and Clouds drive the industry forward, and innovations such as machine learning and artificial intelligence (AI) change the roles of IT and data center professionals, DCD Events aim to bring greater integration across the IT stack, whilst not forgetting the engine. JoinÂ 1,500professionals whose day job it is to keep the digital world up and running. From "mud to cloud", this event covers the full ecosystem, from how data centers are being re-define by the economics of digital business, to how IT and data center service delivery are being re-shaped. WithÂ 100+Â hours of expert panels, keynote presentations, interactive workshops and roundtables, not to mention an expo showcasingÂ 70Â of the latest technologies - This really is an event not to be missed! In less than 48 hours you will network, learn and share your way to a more decisive 2017-18. events.name: Google Cloud Summit, Singapore
events.description: **RSVP'ing at Meetup.com is not sufficient, Please register in the site directly** Registration is now open forÂ Google Cloud Summit in SingaporeÂ on September 21.Â   This event will bring together business and technical executives, decision makers, architects, developers and system administrators to imagine, learn, and build the future of cloud. Whether you are just getting started or well into the adoption of cloud computing, Google Cloud Summit is designed to help you create a cost efficient and secure infrastructure, while getting the most out of world class connectivity, data analytics, machine learning and real-time collaboration. At Google Cloud Summit, you will experience:Â  15 business and technical sessions on all things cloud, including serverless computing, microservices, big data, databases, analytics, machine learning, data protection, managing APIs, Maps and more. Keynotes and two tracks of best-practice enablement practices from our engineers, architects and services teams, as well as our customers and partners. Engage with our network of leading technology partners to accelerate your design, architecture and deployment plans. You will also have the opportunity to network with your industry peers, Googlers and partners throughout the day.Â As space is limited and we expect to reach full capacity soon, we encourage you toÂ reserve your seat today.

events.name: Connecting Things - data networks powering the Internet of Things
events.description:
There is an ever expanding range of options when it comes to connecting things to each other and to the Internet. Besides relatively well known technologies such as Bluetooth, WiFi and 4G cellular, there are also several emerging low-power networking options such as Sigfox, LoRaWAN and NB-IoT.Â 
These low-power wide area network (LPWAN) protocols are an increasingly popular approach for implementing Internet of Things (IoT) solutions. They require fewer base stations to effectively cover entire cities and allow connected device batteries to last dramatically longer, thus enabling the deployment of novel and more efficient connected solutions.
In this roundtable session, we take a closer look at the unique benefits and constraints of the various LPWAN options. Understand how the requirements of your specific application such as data bandwidth, range, security and battery life will dictate the choice of one or some combination of these networks. You will also learn about the wide range of resources available at NUS to augment and accelerate your connected devices innovation efforts.
Join us for lunch on 22-September and get plugged into the dynamic world of IoT data networks.Â 
Program:11:30Â - Registration12:00Â - Overview of emerging IoT data networks by Kelvin Hor of Sigfox12:30 - Introduction to IoT talent, technologies and startups at NUS12:45 - Networking over Lunch
events.location: NUS Enterprise @ SSP, 3 Science Park Drive, #01-06/09, The Franklin, Singapore 118223

events.name: DC ENERGY AND OPERATIONAL EFFICIENCY THROUGH AI
events.description: Large data centres collect data from myriad of heterogeneous sensors from IT and facility systems. These sensors generate massive amount of data, far too large for human analysts to make sense.Â  This work leverages on advanced AI techniques to find clusters of anomalies and perform energy optimization to enhance DC operation and energy efficiency. events.name: TensorFlow and Deep Learning: 8th Event : TF.NEW
events.description: This months event will focus on all things new in TensorFlow and how you can get access to some of them early. We will have Frank Chen from the Google Brain team coming to give a feature presentation about some of the new features being added to the framework over the next few months and how you can make use of them in your models. Martin and Sam will also be giving talks about some of the less known parts of TensorFlow added in the last few versions and how to get access to them without having to wait for new dot releases. We've put the MeetUp start time at 6:45pm, so that we can start the talks promptly at 7pm. --- While we don't have spots for lightning talks this month we are actively looking for some people for October and November forÂ both '30 minutes long-form', and lightning talks where we welcome folks to come up and talk about something cool they've done with TensorFlow and/or Deep Learning for 5-10mins (if you have slides, then #max=10). The key for the Lightning Talks slot is simply the cool/interesting factor.Â  It doesn't matter whether you're an expert or an enthusiastic beginner: Given the responses we have had, we're sure there are lots of people who would be interested to hear what you've been playing with. Please suggest yourself here : https://www.meetup.com/TensorFlow-and-Deep-Learning-Singapore/suggestion/
events.location: Google Asia Pacific, 70 Pasir Panjang Road, #03-71, Mapletree Business City, , Singapore

events.name: ArtScience Late: Tania De Rozario, Pooja Nansi & Cyril Wong
events.description:
ArtScience Late: Speak â€“ Sing â€“ Machinery with Tania De Rozario, Pooja Nansi & Cyril Wong
Thursday, 21 September 2017 | 8pm
Level 4, Expression Gallery
Free on a first-come-first-served basis. Limited capacity.

The machinery of bodies in love, in passionate defiance of limitation and oppression, in tandem with urbanity â€“ both teleological and technological: witness three Singaporean poets as they confess, through verse and music, to the rhythms and revelations of existing meaningfully within the interdependence between a technological world and our enduring humanity. 

About Tania De Rozario 
Tania De Rozario is an artist and writer. She is the author of And The Walls Come Crumbling Down (Math Paper Press, 2016) and Tender Delirium (Math Paper Press, 2013). She was the 2011 winner of the SPH-NAC Golden Point Award for English Poetry, and she runs Etiquette SG, a multidisciplinary platform focused on developing and showcasing art, writing, film and music by women.

About Pooja Nansi
Pooja Nansi is a poet and performer. She is the author of Stiletto Scars and Love is An Empty Barstool. She also curates a monthly spoken word and poetry showcase called Speakeasy at Artistry which plays to packed audiences. Most recently, her one woman show You Are Here was performed at the Esplanade as part of Kalaa Utsavam as well as featured at the Queensland Poetry Festival. She was the NAC-NTU Writer in Residence for 2015-2016 and was also a recipient of the Young Artist Award in 2016.

About Cyril Wong 
Cyril Wong is a poet, fictionist and critic. He was a recipient of the Young Artist Award in 2005 and has been honoured twice with the Singapore Literature Prize â€“ as winner of the English Poetry for Unmarked Treasure in 2006 and as a joint-winner for The Loverâ€™s Inventory in 2016. He has written 16 collections of poems and prose to date, and his works have appeared in several homegrown and international literary anthologies and magazines.  

Sponsored by Coca-Cola

events.name: Book Club: Stanford Machine Learning via Coursera
events.description: We're doing this Machine Learning course from Stanford on CourseraÂ together as a group: https://www.coursera.org/learn/machine-learning Excerpt from course description: This course provides a broad introduction to machine learning, datamining, and statistical pattern recognition. Topics include: â€¢Â Supervised learning (parametric/non-parametric algorithms, support vector machines, kernels, neural networks). â€¢Â Unsupervised learning (clustering, dimensionality reduction, recommender systems, deep learning). â€¢Â Best practices in machine learning (bias/variance theory; innovation process in machine learning and AI).Â  The course will also draw from numerous case studies and applications, so that you'll also learn how to apply learning algorithms to building smart robots (perception, control), text understanding (web search, anti-spam), computer vision, medical informatics, audio, database mining, and other areas. This course runs for 11 Weeks â€“ ends in December and requires between 5 and 10 hours of time per week.Â The course can be taken for free, or for a small fee to Coursera you can have your assignments graded and receive a certificate at the end. Singaporeans are able to claim the course fees withÂ http://www.skillsfuture.sg/. We will be meeting weekly on Thursdays to discuss both lectures and assignments. At each meetup we'll discuss the previous week's lectures and the current assignment. You should have watched the lectures and at least made a start on the assignment, if not completed it. Doors open 7pm. Meetup starts 7:30pm and usually runs to 9:00/9:30pm. Bring dinner/snacks and/or eat beforehand. Press 06160ðŸ”” at the intercom downstairs so we can buzz you in. Note the change of address if you attended previous book club events.
events.location: Tim and Wei's Residence, #06-160, 9 Boon Keng Road, Singapore

events.name: GTS Episode 6: GPU.JS - GPU Accelerated JavaScript
events.description:
gpu.js is a client-side GPGPU library for the browser written entirely in JavaScript. Unlike some currently existing implementations of client-side GPGPU, gpu.js does not require browser support through an explicit GPGPU API or an installation of a custom native runtime browser extension to enable such support. This allows the library to run on all modern platforms, including on mobile devices such as smartphones. It achieves this by using the already widely adopted WebGL graphics API in a manner that it is not designed by making use of JavaScript to GLSL transpilation. The library abstracts away all the unnecessary implementation details of awkwardly performing GPGPU on a graphics API and, at the same time, provides an API that was designed specifically for GPGPU. Speaker Fazli Sapuan Fazli enjoys hacking random stuff together in his free time. As a GPU computing and JavaScript enthusiast, Fazli envisioned an easy way to perform GPGPU inside the browser. Thus, working with a few fellow engineers, gpu.js was created so that it could be used to teach parallel computing concepts to beginners. In this talk, Fazli will describe the inner workings of gpu.js and the challenges he faced while working on gpu.js. 


Schedule 7:00 PM Registration, mingling and Pizza 7:30 PM The Talk 8:30 PM Q & A, and more mingling Our new logo T-shirts and other small perks will be given out upon registration! RSVP now!
events.location: Sea Office, 1 Fusionopolis Place, # 17-10, Galaxis Building, 138522, Singapore, Singapore
